references: Fig.3 visualizes ‖ωi−ωj‖normsubscript𝜔𝑖subscript𝜔𝑗\|\mathbf{\omega}_{i}-\mathbf{\omega}_{j}\|(i,j∈[m]𝑖𝑗delimited-[]𝑚i,j\in[m]) on a synthetic dataset over the course of 600 communication rounds. We use t-distributed stochastic neighbor embedding (t-SNE) [58] to visualize the cluster structure of m=100𝑚100m=100 devices. As can be seen, ωisubscript𝜔𝑖\mathbf{\omega}_{i} converge to four clusters when λ=0.6𝜆0.6\lambda=0.6. These results illustrate that FPFC can effectively identify the cluster structure. Table 1 presents a statistical summary of four metrics on synthetic and H&\&BF datasets. Because LOCAL, FedAvg, LG, and Per-FedAvg lack the capability to cluster devices, we have omitted reporting their Num and ARI results. FedAvg exhibits the worst performance as expected, which can be attributed to its attempt to learn a single model for all devices, despite their distinct data distributions. These results highlight the limitations of FedAvg in terms of individualized predictions and cluster-based analysis. Both Per-FedAvg and LG have shown superior performance compared to FedAvg. This can be attributed to their ability to personalize the global model for each device. Due to overfitting to local data, LOCAL has worse prediction performance than FPFC. The two clustered FL algorithms, IFCA and CFL, do not perform as well as FPFC. Although they can also cluster devices, their clustering performances are inferior to that of FPFC. Although IFCA is implemented with the correct number of clusters, some clusters have no device in the end, resulting in fewer clusters. PACFL demonstrates competitive results, but it relies on a critical threshold parameter that controls the clustering results. FPFC-ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1} performs better than IFCA and CFL in clustering. However, due to the use of ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1} penalty in FPFC-ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}, when the coefficients of devices that belong to different clusters have significant differences, FPFC-ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1} imposes a stronger penalty to compress these coefficients, leading to incorrect grouping. In contrast, FPFC does not penalize large coefficient differences, and therefore the result of FPFC-ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1} is significantly inferior to FPFC in both clustering and prediction. LOCAL incurs zero communication costs as it does not involve any communication with the server. FedAvg, LG, Per-FedAvg, FPFC, and FPFC-ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1} have the same communication costs due to the consistent size of the transmitted information at each communication round. The communication cost of PACFL is determined by the combined cost of FedAvg and the cost associated with hierarchical clustering in one-shot clustering. IFCA has the highest communication cost due to its sensitivity to initialization, which needs more communication rounds to achieve convergence. Additionally, during each communication round, IFCA requires downloading all cluster models to all devices, resulting in a substantial increase in communication costs.

S6.T2.caption: Table 2: Selected λ𝜆\lambda by two strategies and running time on synthetic, H&BF, MNIST, and FMNIST datasets.
S6.T2.table:
Synthetic H&BF MNIST FMNIST
λ𝜆\lambda Time λ𝜆\lambda Time λ𝜆\lambda Time λ𝜆\lambda Time
Separate 0.5 4.02h 4 39.41s 0.1 3.94h 0.1 2.80h
Warmup 3 0.46h 4 14.74s 0.4 0.58h 0.6 0.59h
references: The four subgraphs in the second row of Fig. 6 show the generalization performance of the two strategies. For FPFC with separate tuning, the initial values corresponding to each λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} are randomly generated. Subsequently, we run FPFC using λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} on the training set and assess its performance (accuracy or RMSE) on the validation set. Finally, we compute the testing accuracy/RMSE of FPFC using the λ𝜆\lambda that shows the best performance on the validation set. Take the synthetic dataset as an example, the testing accuracies during 0-68th communication rounds are obtained based on the models with λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0. The 69th-443th, 444th-458th, 459th-463th, 464th-605th, 606th-623th, 624th-634th, 635th-780th testing results are based on models with λ=0.5,1,1.5,2,2.5,3,3.5𝜆0.511.522.533.5\lambda=0.5,1,1.5,2,2.5,3,3.5, respectively. Due to the lower validation accuracy observed with λ=3.5𝜆3.5\lambda=3.5 compared to λ=3𝜆3\lambda=3, we finally run the latest model trained with λ=3𝜆3\lambda=3 from the 635th communication round and continue running it until the maximum number of iterations is reached. During the warmup stage, the initial values associated with the subsequent λ𝜆\lambda values gradually converge towards local minimizers. As a result, using better initial values can potentially yield improved results. The final selected regularization parameter and total running time are reported in Table 2. Utilizing the warmup scheme significantly reduces the running time, for example, reducing it to 0.58 hours with warmup compared to 3.94 hours when tuning parameters separately on the MNIST dataset.

references: To evaluate the performance of newcomers’ models, we consider three scenarios where 20% of the participants join the federated network after the federated training process. Table 3 reports the average local test accuracy and standard deviation of the newcomers on three different datasets. As observed, FedAvg has the worst performance as the global model is not well-suited for all devices. The two personalized baselines, LG and Per-FedAvg, outperform FedAvg as they enable newcomers to fine-tune the global model based on their local data. Compared to other baselines, FPFC has comparable performance and demonstrates good generalization capabilities on various datasets.

Because LOCAL, FedAvg, LG, and Per-FedAvg lack the capability to cluster devices, we have omitted reporting their Num and ARI results. FedAvg exhibits the worst performance as expected, which can be attributed to its attempt to learn a single model for all devices, despite their distinct data distributions. These results highlight the limitations of FedAvg in terms of individualized predictions and cluster-based analysis. Both Per-FedAvg and LG have shown superior performance compared to FedAvg. The two clustered FL algorithms, IFCA and CFL, do not perform as well as FPFC. Although they can also cluster devices, their clustering performances are inferior to that of FPFC. Although IFCA is implemented with the correct number of clusters, some clusters have no device in the end, resulting in fewer clusters. PACFL demonstrates competitive results, but it relies on a critical threshold parameter that controls the clustering results. FPFC-ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1} performs better than IFCA and CFL in clustering. However, due to the use of ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1} penalty in FPFC-ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}, when the coefficients of devices that belong to different clusters have significant differences, FPFC-ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1} imposes a stronger penalty to compress these coefficients, leading to incorrect grouping. In contrast, FPFC does not penalize large coefficient differences, and therefore the result of FPFC-ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1} is significantly inferior to FPFC in both clustering and prediction. LOCAL incurs zero communication costs as it does not involve any communication with the server. FedAvg, LG, Per-FedAvg, FPFC, and FPFC-ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1} have the same communication costs due to the consistent size of the transmitted information at each communication round. The communication cost of PACFL is determined by the combined cost of FedAvg and the cost associated with hierarchical clustering in one-shot clustering. IFCA has the highest communication cost due to its sensitivity to initialization, which needs more communication rounds to achieve convergence. Additionally, during each communication round, IFCA requires downloading all cluster models to all devices, resulting in a substantial increase in communication costs.

The four subgraphs in the second row of Fig. 6 show the generalization performance of the two strategies. For FPFC with separate tuning, the initial values corresponding to each λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} are randomly generated. Subsequently, we run FPFC using λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} on the training set and assess its performance (accuracy or RMSE) on the validation set. Finally, we compute the testing accuracy/RMSE of FPFC using the λ𝜆\lambda that shows the best performance on the validation set. Take the synthetic dataset as an example, the testing accuracies during 0-68th communication rounds are obtained based on the models with λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0. The 69th-443th, 444th-458th, 459th-463th, 464th-605th, 606th-623th, 624th-634th, 635th-780th testing results are based on models with λ=0.5,1,1.5,2,2.5,3,3.5𝜆0.511.522.533.5\lambda=0.5,1,1.5,2,2.5,3,3.5, respectively. Due to the lower validation accuracy observed with λ=3.5𝜆3.5\lambda=3.5 compared to λ=3𝜆3\lambda=3, we finally run the latest model trained with λ=3𝜆3\lambda=3 from the 635th communication round and continue running it until the maximum number of iterations is reached. During the warmup stage, the initial values associated with the subsequent λ𝜆\lambda values gradually converge towards local minimizers. As a result, using better initial values can potentially yield improved results. The final selected regularization parameter and total running time are reported in Table 2. Utilizing the warmup scheme significantly reduces the running time, for example, reducing it to 0.58 hours with warmup compared to 3.94 hours when tuning parameters separately on the MNIST dataset.

To evaluate the robustness of the personalization layers in the model, we conduct experiments involving attacks with varying levels of noise. For the three Byzantine attacks, the noise level σ𝜎\sigma is set as 100,10,10010010100100,10,100 respectively, as specified in [37]. We consider different ratios of malicious devices, ranging from 0.0 to 0.8 with increments of 0.2. Fig.7 shows the average test accuracy of benign devices on the FMNIST dataset for different methods under the three Byzantine attacks. As we can see, FPFC consistently outperforms other baselines and it is the most stable algorithm across different attack scenarios. For full results on synthetic and MNIST datasets, please refer to Appendix E.2.

To evaluate the performance of newcomers’ models, we consider three scenarios where 20% of the participants join the federated network after the federated training process. Table 3 reports the average local test accuracy and standard deviation of the newcomers on three different datasets. As observed, FedAvg has the worst performance as the global model is not well-suited for all devices. The two personalized baselines, LG and Per-FedAvg, outperform FedAvg as they enable newcomers to fine-tune the global model based on their local data. Compared to other baselines, FPFC has comparable performance and demonstrates good generalization capabilities on various datasets.

Table E.1 reports the results for scenario S2, i.e., unbalanced cluster structure with L=4𝐿4L=4. FPFC has favorable clustering performance. It can be observed that only FPFC can identify the general cluster structure and the overestimation of the number of clusters is due to the over-subdivision of two small clusters. The results of scenario S3 are presented in Table E.2. FPFC has the best or close to the best performance in prediction and clustering. Tables E.3 and E.4 list the results of scenarios S4 and S5. It can be seen that in the two worst scenarios, i.e., unstructured with L=1𝐿1L=1 and personalized with L=m𝐿𝑚L=m, our FPFC still has competitive performance; in particular, it still can identify the cluster structure exactly, suggesting that FPFC is a safe choice in practice.

In FPFC, the regularization parameter λ𝜆\lambda controls the strength of fusion penalty. When λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0, the penalty is absent, and the original model will degenerate into the fully personalized model; When λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty, all devices will be shrunk into one cluster, and the original model will degenerate into the global model in standard FL. Fig. E.4 presents the testing RMSE/accuracy as a function of λ𝜆\lambda on different datasets. Take synthetic data as an example, it can be observed that as λ𝜆\lambda increases, the testing accuracy increases at first, peaks at approximately λ=0.6𝜆0.6\lambda=0.6, and then decreases, implying that a suitable λ𝜆\lambda can improve prediction performance.

The four subgraphs in the second row of Fig. 6 show the generalization performance of the two strategies. Finally, we compute the testing accuracy/RMSE of FPFC using the λ𝜆\lambda that shows the best performance on the validation set. Take the synthetic dataset as an example, the testing accuracies during 0-68th communication rounds are obtained based on the models with λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0. To evaluate the robustness of the personalization layers in the model, we conduct experiments involving attacks with varying levels of noise. For the three Byzantine attacks, the noise level σ𝜎\sigma is set as 100,10,10010010100100,10,100 respectively, as specified in [37]. We consider different ratios of malicious devices, ranging from 0.0 to 0.8 with increments of 0.2. Fig.7 shows the average test accuracy of benign devices on the FMNIST dataset for different methods under the three Byzantine attacks. As we can see, FPFC consistently outperforms other baselines and it is the most stable algorithm across different attack scenarios. For full results on synthetic and MNIST datasets, please refer to Appendix E.2.

To evaluate the performance of newcomers’ models, we consider three scenarios where 20% of the participants join the federated network after the federated training process. Table 3 reports the average local test accuracy and standard deviation of the newcomers on three different datasets. As observed, FedAvg has the worst performance as the global model is not well-suited for all devices. The two personalized baselines, LG and Per-FedAvg, outperform FedAvg as they enable newcomers to fine-tune the global model based on their local data. Compared to other baselines, FPFC has comparable performance and demonstrates good generalization capabilities on various datasets.

Table E.1 reports the results for scenario S2, i.e., unbalanced cluster structure with L=4𝐿4L=4. FPFC has favorable clustering performance. It can be seen that in the two worst scenarios, i.e., unstructured with L=1𝐿1L=1 and personalized with L=m𝐿𝑚L=m, our FPFC still has competitive performance; in particular, it still can identify the cluster structure exactly, suggesting that FPFC is a safe choice in practice.

In FPFC, the regularization parameter λ𝜆\lambda controls the strength of fusion penalty. When λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0, the penalty is absent, and the original model will degenerate into the fully personalized model; When λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty, all devices will be shrunk into one cluster, and the original model will degenerate into the global model in standard FL. references: Fig.3 visualizes ‖ωi−ωj‖normsubscript𝜔𝑖subscript𝜔𝑗\|\mathbf{\omega}_{i}-\mathbf{\omega}_{j}\|(i,j∈[m]𝑖𝑗delimited-[]𝑚i,j\in[m]) on a synthetic dataset over the course of 600 communication rounds. We use t-distributed stochastic neighbor embedding (t-SNE) [58] to visualize the cluster structure of m=100𝑚100m=100 devices. As can be seen, ωisubscript𝜔𝑖\mathbf{\omega}_{i} converge to four clusters when λ=0.6𝜆0.6\lambda=0.6. These results illustrate that FPFC can effectively identify the cluster structure. Table 1 presents a statistical summary of four metrics on synthetic and H&\&BF datasets. Because LOCAL, FedAvg, LG, and Per-FedAvg lack the capability to cluster devices, we have omitted reporting their Num and ARI results. FedAvg exhibits the worst performance as expected, which can be attributed to its attempt to learn a single model for all devices, despite their distinct data distributions. These results highlight the limitations of FedAvg in terms of individualized predictions and cluster-based analysis. Both Per-FedAvg and LG have shown superior performance compared to FedAvg. This can be attributed to their ability to personalize the global model for each device. Due to overfitting to local data, LOCAL has worse prediction performance than FPFC. The two clustered FL algorithms, IFCA and CFL, do not perform as well as FPFC. Although they can also cluster devices, their clustering performances are inferior to that of FPFC. Although IFCA is implemented with the correct number of clusters, some clusters have no device in the end, resulting in fewer clusters. PACFL demonstrates competitive results, but it relies on a critical threshold parameter that controls the clustering results. FPFC-ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1} performs better than IFCA and CFL in clustering. However, due to the use of ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1} penalty in FPFC-ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}, when the coefficients of devices that belong to different clusters have significant differences, FPFC-ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1} imposes a stronger penalty to compress these coefficients, leading to incorrect grouping. In contrast, FPFC does not penalize large coefficient differences, and therefore the result of FPFC-ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1} is significantly inferior to FPFC in both clustering and prediction. LOCAL incurs zero communication costs as it does not involve any communication with the server. FedAvg, LG, Per-FedAvg, FPFC, and FPFC-ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1} have the same communication costs due to the consistent size of the transmitted information at each communication round. The communication cost of PACFL is determined by the combined cost of FedAvg and the cost associated with hierarchical clustering in one-shot clustering. IFCA has the highest communication cost due to its sensitivity to initialization, which needs more communication rounds to achieve convergence. Additionally, during each communication round, IFCA requires downloading all cluster models to all devices, resulting in a substantial increase in communication costs.

The four subgraphs in the second row of Fig. 6 show the generalization performance of the two strategies. For FPFC with separate tuning, the initial values corresponding to each λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} are randomly generated. Subsequently, we run FPFC using λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} on the training set and assess its performance (accuracy or RMSE) on the validation set. Finally, we compute the testing accuracy/RMSE of FPFC using the λ𝜆\lambda that shows the best performance on the validation set. Take the synthetic dataset as an example, the testing accuracies during 0-68th communication rounds are obtained based on the models with λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0. The 69th-443th, 444th-458th, 459th-463th, 464th-605th, 606th-623th, 624th-634th, 635th-780th testing results are based on models with λ=0.5,1,1.5,2,2.5,3,3.5𝜆0.511.522.533.5\lambda=0.5,1,1.5,2,2.5,3,3.5, respectively. Due to the lower validation accuracy observed with λ=3.5𝜆3.5\lambda=3.5 compared to λ=3𝜆3\lambda=3, we finally run the latest model trained with λ=3𝜆3\lambda=3 from the 635th communication round and continue running it until the maximum number of iterations is reached. During the warmup stage, the initial values associated with the subsequent λ𝜆\lambda values gradually converge towards local minimizers. As a result, using better initial values can potentially yield improved results. The final selected regularization parameter and total running time are reported in Table 2. Utilizing the warmup scheme significantly reduces the running time, for example, reducing it to 0.58 hours with warmup compared to 3.94 hours when tuning parameters separately on the MNIST dataset.

To evaluate the robustness of the personalization layers in the model, we conduct experiments involving attacks with varying levels of noise. For the three Byzantine attacks, the noise level σ𝜎\sigma is set as 100,10,10010010100100,10,100 respectively, as specified in [37]. We consider different ratios of malicious devices, ranging from 0.0 to 0.8 with increments of 0.2. Fig.7 shows the average test accuracy of benign devices on the FMNIST dataset for different methods under the three Byzantine attacks. As we can see, FPFC consistently outperforms other baselines and it is the most stable algorithm across different attack scenarios. For full results on synthetic and MNIST datasets, please refer to Appendix E.2.

To evaluate the performance of newcomers’ models, we consider three scenarios where 20% of the participants join the federated network after the federated training process. Table 3 reports the average local test accuracy and standard deviation of the newcomers on three different datasets. As observed, FedAvg has the worst performance as the global model is not well-suited for all devices. The two personalized baselines, LG and Per-FedAvg, outperform FedAvg as they enable newcomers to fine-tune the global model based on their local data. Compared to other baselines, FPFC has comparable performance and demonstrates good generalization capabilities on various datasets.

Table E.1 reports the results for scenario S2, i.e., unbalanced cluster structure with L=4𝐿4L=4. FPFC has favorable clustering performance. It can be observed that only FPFC can identify the general cluster structure and the overestimation of the number of clusters is due to the over-subdivision of two small clusters. The results of scenario S3 are presented in Table E.2. FPFC has the best or close to the best performance in prediction and clustering. Tables E.3 and E.4 list the results of scenarios S4 and S5. It can be seen that in the two worst scenarios, i.e., unstructured with L=1𝐿1L=1 and personalized with L=m𝐿𝑚L=m, our FPFC still has competitive performance; in particular, it still can identify the cluster structure exactly, suggesting that FPFC is a safe choice in practice.

In FPFC, the regularization parameter λ𝜆\lambda controls the strength of fusion penalty. When λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0, the penalty is absent, and the original model will degenerate into the fully personalized model; When λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty, all devices will be shrunk into one cluster, and the original model will degenerate into the global model in standard FL. Fig. E.4 presents the testing RMSE/accuracy as a function of λ𝜆\lambda on different datasets. Take synthetic data as an example, it can be observed that as λ𝜆\lambda increases, the testing accuracy increases at first, peaks at approximately λ=0.6𝜆0.6\lambda=0.6, and then decreases, implying that a suitable λ𝜆\lambda can improve prediction performance.

The four subgraphs in the second row of Fig. 6 show the generalization performance of the two strategies. For FPFC with separate tuning, the initial values corresponding to each λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} are randomly generated. Subsequently, we run FPFC using λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} on the training set and assess its performance (accuracy or RMSE) on the validation set. Finally, we compute the testing accuracy/RMSE of FPFC using the λ𝜆\lambda that shows the best performance on the validation set. Take the synthetic dataset as an example, the testing accuracies during 0-68th communication rounds are obtained based on the models with λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0. The 69th-443th, 444th-458th, 459th-463th, 464th-605th, 606th-623th, 624th-634th, 635th-780th testing results are based on models with λ=0.5,1,1.5,2,2.5,3,3.5𝜆0.511.522.533.5\lambda=0.5,1,1.5,2,2.5,3,3.5, respectively. Utilizing the warmup scheme significantly reduces the running time, for example, reducing it to 0.58 hours with warmup compared to 3.94 hours when tuning parameters separately on the MNIST dataset.

To evaluate the robustness of the personalization layers in the model, we conduct experiments involving attacks with varying levels of noise. For the three Byzantine attacks, the noise level σ𝜎\sigma is set as 100,10,10010010100100,10,100 respectively, as specified in [37]. We consider different ratios of malicious devices, ranging from 0.0 to 0.8 with increments of 0.2. Fig.7 shows the average test accuracy of benign devices on the FMNIST dataset for different methods under the three Byzantine attacks. As we can see, FPFC consistently outperforms other baselines and it is the most stable algorithm across different attack scenarios. For full results on synthetic and MNIST datasets, please refer to Appendix E.2.

To evaluate the performance of newcomers’ models, we consider three scenarios where 20% of the participants join the federated network after the federated training process. Table 3 reports the average local test accuracy and standard deviation of the newcomers on three different datasets. As observed, FedAvg has the worst performance as the global model is not well-suited for all devices. The two personalized baselines, LG and Per-FedAvg, outperform FedAvg as they enable newcomers to fine-tune the global model based on their local data. Compared to other baselines, FPFC has comparable performance and demonstrates good generalization capabilities on various datasets.

Table E.1 reports the results for scenario S2, i.e., unbalanced cluster structure with L=4𝐿4L=4. FPFC has favorable clustering performance. It can be observed that only FPFC can identify the general cluster structure and the overestimation of the number of clusters is due to the over-subdivision of two small clusters. The results of scenario S3 are presented in Table E.2. FPFC has the best or close to the best performance in prediction and clustering. Tables E.3 and E.4 list the results of scenarios S4 and S5. It can be seen that in the two worst scenarios, i.e., unstructured with L=1𝐿1L=1 and personalized with L=m𝐿𝑚L=m, our FPFC still has competitive performance; in particular, it still can identify the cluster structure exactly, suggesting that FPFC is a safe choice in practice.

In FPFC, the regularization parameter λ𝜆\lambda controls the strength of fusion penalty. When λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0, the penalty is absent, and the original model will degenerate into the fully personalized model; When λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty, all devices will be shrunk into one cluster, and the original model will degenerate into the global model in standard FL. Fig. E.4 presents the testing RMSE/accuracy as a function of λ𝜆\lambda on different datasets. Take synthetic data as an example, it can be observed that as λ𝜆\lambda increases, the testing accuracy increases at first, peaks at approximately λ=0.6𝜆0.6\lambda=0.6, and then decreases, implying that a suitable λ𝜆\lambda can improve prediction performance.
